captions.text: [CAR ENGINE]

MIKE MUSTO: Today on "Big
Muscle," we've got a 1966

Chevrolet Chevelle with
604 horsepower and
a wicked bad attitude.

So hang on, because today is
going to be outstanding.

Seriously, it's going
to be good.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MIKE MUSTO: My name
is Mike Musto.

Each week, I travel the country
with the goal of

showcasing the best and baddest
muscle cars and hot
rods around.

Every car has a past, and
every owner, a story.

Welcome to the world
of "Big Muscle."
[CAR ENGINES ROARING]

ENZO MORALES: Today we're
looking at my 1966 Chevy
Chevelle Malibu.

I've been working on the car
for about four years.

I bought it at the tail end of
2008 during the whole economic

downfall there, as strictly
a stress reliever.

And it slowly evolved into kind
of like the dream car.

And over the course of the last
four years, with the help

of a lot of friends, I was able
to put this car together.

We've got it running now
for about four months.

And it's really just been ideal
as far as what I wanted,

what I pictured, and what the
end result ended up being as

far as the performance, the
reliability, and just the

overall driveability
of the car.
[CAR ENGINE]
[TIRES SQUEALING]

MIKE MUSTO: Ladies and
gentlemen, welcome to another

episode of "Big Muscle." Today,
we are driving the 1966
Chevrolet Malibu Chevelle.

You know, it's a car that, while
it may look like a pro

touring car, it was actually
developed by Enzo to be more
of a kind of a grand tourer.

When you design a grand touring
car, you want a couple
of things, right?
You want a comfortable ride.
You want compliant suspension.
You want great brakes.

And you want halfway
decent gas mileage.

And that's something he's
actually managed to encompass

in this car and to incorporate
very, very well.
You know, from a looks
standpoint, it's very sinister.

The gloss black paint with the
bronze striped wheels lend to

look that is very, very
kind of intimidating.

But I'll be honest with you,
once you get in this thing and

you start driving it, it's
really anything but.

Engine-wise, we're talking about
an LS3 that's been kind

of massaged by Nelson Racing
Engines to the tune of just a
tad over 600 horsepower.
And I mean, the car goes.

I mean, you roll into it,
and it'll basically
just pull for days.

I mean, the transmission is a
T56 out of a 2002 Trans Am,

and, to be honest, I mean,
it shifts flawlessly.

One thing I do have to say,
though, is the clutch is a
sledgehammer.

I mean, this is not a car
that I want to get
stuck in traffic with.

Now, you're looking at me
driving this thing, right?

And I've got my hands on
basically what seems to be
like a 20-inch steering wheel.

I mean, this is pizza
pie size.
But it works.

The way that Enzo did this
interior was by combining new
and old, right?

And of course, we've showcased
you guys' cars
before that do that.

They take a little bit of new
and a little bit of old, and
they meld it together.

Well, what Enzo did was he kept
it primarily old school.

The dash is 100% stock with
tiny, tiny little differences.

So, for instance, there are
numbers on the temp gauge as
opposed to just low and high.

The door panels, this looks like
they're bone stock, but
they're not.

Enzo actually took a lot of
time and sat down with a

designer to say, this is how I
want the car to be portrayed.
[CAR ENGINE]

ENZO MORALES: Well, the
interior, there was definitely
some purpose behind it.

I'm not as svelte as
I look on camera.
I'm 6' 3", about 235 pounds.

So I had to design interior
around my comfort.

One of the big things I've
noticed about newer cars is

the ergonomics as far as when
you're sitting in the car, the

comfort level that you achieve
by just putting yourself

elbows down in certain areas
or where the shifter is
positioned.

So when I went to talk to Mark
Lopez up at Elegance

Interiors, we literally sat down
for probably four hours

on his desk, and I made him
sketch everything out.

He had the car for about
2 and 1/2 weeks.
He listened to what I wanted.

He achieved it, I feel,
in the way that he
put in interior together.

What we did is we basically
created a 7/8-style rear seat

that he fabricated that makes
the interior look actually

larger than it is when you look
in through the window.

The seats are all the way back,
and when they're all the

way back, my leg can't actually
disengage the clutch
all the way.

I have to actually
click it up.

So those little things for
me were important.

Leg room, you know, being able
to put my kids behind me while
I'm in the car.

All of the interior cues are
taken from the '60s as far as

the original styling
of the car.

But we just modernized it a
little bit, created a little

bit more of an aggressive
attitude, and then just
refined it.
[CAR ENGINE]

MIKE MUSTO: The suspension,
the guys at RideTech did a

great job, a great job on giving
him a set of single
adjustables for this thing.

You don't need triple
adjustables on a car like

this, because, I'll be honest
with you, it's just overkill.

This thing is more of a set
it and forgot it type of
automobile.

Cruising like this is
all fine and dandy.
And it's great--

cruising along, 60 miles
an hour, no big deal.

But again, you take
this car, right?
What do you do?
You drop it down a gear--
[CAR ENGINE]
MIKE MUSTO: --whack it.
[CAR ENGINE]

MIKE MUSTO: It frickin'
pulls, man.

Well, that's as Matt Farah
would say, that's
possible jail time.

So let's just leave
it at that.
School zone.
-Flip the bitch.
Get out of here.

MIKE MUSTO: Flip the bitch
in the school zone
because they love that.
-For the kids, Mike.
MIKE MUSTO: For the kids.
-Do it for the kids, Mike.

MIKE MUSTO: Do it
for the kids.
-You know what you have to do.
MIKE MUSTO: What's up, kids?
I've got kids over here.

They're motioning for
me to do a burnout.

However, I'm not going
to do a burnout?
Why?

Because we're in
a school zone.

-You should still
do a burnout.

MIKE MUSTO: I'm not
doing a burnout.
-You should do a burnout.
It's for the kids.

MIKE MUSTO: I'm not doing
a burnout for the kids!
-Do a burnout for the kids.

MIKE MUSTO: I'm not doing
a burnout in a school
zone for the kids.

Now the school zone sign said
we're ended, so now we can go.
[TIRES SQUEALING]

MIKE MUSTO: A lot of people ask
me, they're like, how do

you review a car and what
do you look for?

And my answer is well, we review
it based on what the

owner says he wanted
to do with the car.

In Enzo's case, he wanted to
build a great grand touring

car that can not only go from
point A to point B hundreds of

miles away in complete comfort,
but I wanted a car

could handle, brake, turn, and
do all the things that a good
grand touring car should do.

So we did the on-road portion,
where we just kind of did the
distance style thing.

And now what we're doing is
we're cruising through the

canyons, and we're going to do
the handling, the braking.

I'm going to tell
you how it is.
It shifts beautifully.
We can go down.

We can rumble through
the gears, OK?

Come into a corner,
hit the brakes.

The brakes are off a Z06
Corvette, and they're manual.
Turn the car in.

Now, we're not doing
anything crazy.

It's not like we're going
monumental speeds.

But what we're doing is putting
the car through kind

of a little handling course just
to get an idea if there's

body roll, if there's any
squeaks, if there's any

rattles, and to kind of see how
the whole package works in
conjunction with each other.
The car so far is great.

Manual brakes, if you're not
used to them, they take a
little getting used to.

But they stop the car
absolutely fine.
You go in.
You feel the steering, right?
You turn in.

Even with this big
wheel, how is it?

Well, it's actually
really nice.

Look, there's no roll
in the car.

The seats, even though they're
not high back seats, are

holding me in just fine going
through the corner, right?
[LAUGHING]

MIKE MUSTO: The car
handles great.

And you've got to remember
that a '66 Chevelle
is not a small car.
These are big cars.

They're heavy cars with
a long wheelbase, OK?

We drove a '66 Chevelle last
season, and it was a fabulous,

fabulous car, but with such a
different personality than

this, even though they're
the same make and model.

That's the beauty
of the hobby.
You can differentiate.
You can have fun.
You can enjoy.

And at day's end, you can pull
up to the exact same car make

and model and have something
completely different.
[CAR ENGINE]

ENZO MORALES: Having been born
in Peru, I came here in 1981
when I was six years old.

The first car I rode in, my dad
was actually borrowing a

car from his brother was,
I think, a 1969 911T.

And it was my absolute first
experience in any kind of a

performance vehicle ever,
and it changed my world.

I mean, from that point forward,
I became overly
obsessed with four wheels.

I think ultimately, the guy that
was kind of driving that

a little bit from behind
was my dad.

He just kind of always liked
that I was into it.

When he was 18 and he lived
in Long Beach--

he had been here in the States
for a while back then--

he bought a 1957
Chevy Bel Air.

And so when I was 14 and 1/2,
almost 15 years old, he bought

a '57 Bel Air for me, and that's
what kind of took me to
where I'm at today.

I had this ideal group of
friends when I was growing up.

We used to sit around late
nights when we were 15, 16

years old, reading car
magazines, talking about what
we wanted to build.

And slowly but surely, we
all kind of elevated
each others' games.

By the time we were 18, 19 years
old, we were driving

11-second cars on the street,
delivering pizzas, literally.

One of my best friends became a
very famous engine builder,

although his car was terribly
slow during those times and I

beat him every single
time we raced.

For those of you who don't know,
it's Tom Nelson from

Nelson Racing Engines, who
I credit to building this
wonderful engine.

He was one of the guys
who contributed
to the build, but--
just for the record--
never beat me in a drag race.

But anyway, I was very
fortunate, because it really
kept us all out of trouble.

I mean, we were all guys that
probably would have gone down

different paths were
it not for cars.
The cars really saved us.

And that's really what I
attribute to the friendships
that I had when I was a kid.
[CAR ENGINE]

MIKE MUSTO: One of the things
about talking to Enzo is that

he's got a massive personality,
and it's really
kind of infectious.

I mean, you talk to him,
and he gets excited.
And he starts telling stories.

And then you get excited
listening to his stories.
And you're like, goddammit.

And the reason you say goddammit
is because you don't

a story that's as good as his
story about the stuff that he
did when he was a kid.

I mean, drag racing and doing
this and running from the

cops, which you should
never do.

But, I mean, not only does this
guy have a great family,
he's got an awesome car.
He's got a kick-ass job.
Not--

I mean, we have pretty
cool job, too.
I'm not going to lie to you.

But I guess in the end, what's
really cool is it's nice to

see good people have
good things.

And it's nice to see somebody
who had a vision from the
beginning develop.
This is why we do what we do.

This is why we're in the desert
right now in this
awesome Chevelle.

If I can't convince you that
stuff like this is cool, I am
so not doing my job right.
[CAR ENGINE]

MIKE MUSTO: Sometimes on this
show, when all the pieces fall

perfectly into place, we realize
just how lucky we are.

Like the time we drove a blown
Cadillac down the Pacific
Coast Highway.

Or when we did burnouts
in a GT500 Mustang.

Or maybe it was the time when we
are ripping up the canyons
in a Corvette-crushing 69 AMX.

Those are the type of things
we live for on the show.

Today, too, was one
of those days.

For as the sunset and the day
came to a close, we knew we

had just experienced a car where
all the time, energy,

and parts worked perfectly
together.
Man, hot day, hot day.

Oh wait, how do we
get out of here?
The gate that's now closed.
Where's the stop sign?
Can you come in this way?
No.
Is this right?
How do we get out?
Are we going all the way down?
What the [BLEEP].

Tell the guys to go out that
way, because there's
no exit over here.
Whew.
Sweaty hot.

This gate opens inward,
doesn't it?
-Yeah.
-What?
MIKE MUSTO: How do we get out?

Speaking of Aston, the 1970s AMV8V... *that* is a muscle car.﻿
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
+Militant Monkey If you got a DB4 you could pretend you were Charlie Croker 
from The Italian Job... :P
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
+Foxtrot Oscar I agree that the DB4 is perhaps a marginally better looking 
car because it's marginally different but for me, it's the whole James Bond 
thing that tips it.

I can't think of any other cars that have that.
comments.author: Mr English

comments.text:
+Militant Monkey Light and airy. I just think the front matches the back 
better with the DB4 than 5.
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
+Foxtrot Oscar There's the headlights but i find the whole style of the car 
looks more pointy. The DB5 looks a bit fatter.
comments.author: Mr English

comments.text:
+Militant Monkey Of course. Though I can always picture Bond having a DB4. 
Mainly because they're almost identical outside, bar the headlights. Just 
any Aston Martin in general makes you feel a little bit like Bond. However, 
it's only the DB5 that'll get everyone else feeling the vibe too.
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
+Foxtrot Oscar Yeah the DB4 as a "car vs car" is obviously the clear 
winner. The thing is, the DB5 has now been romanticized, it not just a car 
now but a culture icon. Apart from people like me and yourself, not many 
could identify a DB4. A DB5 however stands for something much more than 
JUST a car  but it's an whole alter-persona people just wish they could 
have.

http://hqwallpapers.org/wallpapers/l/1366x768/22/james_bond_daniel_craig_aston_martin_db5_1366x768_21849.jpg


 
I don't want the DB5 because of the car, i want the DB5 because it's the 
only car that could make me James Bond. The car, the suit, the gun, the MAN.

Stepping back into the real world though and as a "car" enthusiast..it 
would have to be DB4.
comments.author: Mr English

comments.text:
+Militant Monkey For me, the DB4 is the clear victor. It's the original car 
of that shape, before the DB5 got a new front end, and the DB6 then got a 
new rear end. It looks proper, and pretty, and very,very late 50s Italian 
with a dash of British stiff upper lip which is utterly gorgeous.

Bond's BMW moment was pure marketing bollocks. They never came to much and 
no one gives a hoot about them, so no harm done.
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
+Foxtrot Oscar By the way i'm red winter, i've just change my name, we've 
talked about this in the past.

For me picking between DB4 (GTZ) and DB5 is like picking between your mum 
and dad kind of thing. Either way, you'd fell bad for the other making a 
choice.

The only thing that would sway it for is if the DB5 had all the bondy bells 
and whistles. I know Aston Martin do one but i'm not sure weather it's a 
conversion or a replica but you can pay them to do it by their special 
projects team. 

p.s

Bond was close to being a Jag man too and he's had the famous lotus. All is 
fine because they are British brands but why the heck did he have a mad 
moment with BMW?
comments.author: Mr English

comments.text:
Bond was originally a Bentley man, however he did eventually acquire a DB 
mk3 in the original books. The film Goldfinger, however, is the Bond-car 
combo everyone remembers and loves. DB5.. it just sounds right.
I prefer the DB4 though.
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
+Foxtrot Oscar Obviously a AMV8V from the 70s is a muscle car, i'd call the 
90s one a muscle car too. I fell in love with the 70s AMV8V when James Bond 
drove one....fucking LOVED IT.

I think the V8V did to James Bond back then, what Daniel Craig did for 
James Bond now...made him more of a serious, darker character than the 
witty and classy Rodger or Connery. Scuze if i'm blabbering on but talking 
about Astons and James Bond goes hand in hand in my book. It's just a 
British cult thing.
comments.author: Mr English

comments.text:
+1400IntruderVS Eh, I work on them so that I can make a living. In fact, 
the XJ12 I pulled out of a barn age 17 and set to work.
Jaguar were actually doing ok independently. They've always been small but 
profitable.
It's been nothing but reliable for the past 10 years, and I didn't even do 
that good of a job getting it going. It took 6 years to paint the thing 
properly.
Yes, they're demanding. Then again, all 42 year old cars are demanding, and 
very, very few are this sophisticated. The rest that are tend to be of the 
Rolls Royce, Bentley, Ferrari or Aston Martin favour and require a *lot* 
more attention. In terms of performance and quality to time needed, they 
strike a pretty good balance. 
Why the hell would I talk American dollars?
Oil leaks? Nah. With the V12 there aren't any, because I made sure I did 
everything right, used decent quality seals and didn't twist anything. Same 
with the E type and D type except I also replaced the crank seals because 
the original rope design was just... crap. But then, that's all they had in 
1945 when the engine was designed. Pretty impressive that it lasted until 
the 90s then, eh?
Electrical fires? Nope. I had to replace the rodent-eaten wiring but all 
the original *Lucas* switchgear and relays and shit is still there.

I'm not claiming any car is the best, just that some are better than 
others.
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
Dude I work on these things for a living. Jags are inefficiently designed 
 mechanical monstrosities that are in the shop more than on the road and 
would have gone belly up if Ford did not invest in them at that time. And I 
would have one if they weren't so damn demanding when it comes to 
maintenance and repair. I don't know where your price spec came from 
because I spent a lot time online trying to find the lowest and 5500 was 
the that.(perhaps your not talking American dollars in the US?) Maybe you 
just purchased a car that some one got an insane deal on.  I will not argue 
the merits of any manufacturer because really a side fro Porsche no one 
really impresses me. I cn't believe a jag fan would open their wallet and 
throw in their two cents in any discussion about automobiles given their 
notorious reputation for oil leaks and electrical fires, but I will side 
with your love for great character and good handling. when they work right 
they are really right. 
Unfortunately for this discussion I had only made a comment about the 
marketing origins of thee American Musclecars and wlked right in to your 
blabbering about who does what better than when for what ever reason.
People love different cars for different reasons I love many machines for 
different reasons but I do not pretend that my opinion is what makes 
something better than all the rest. 
If that were the case Porsche would be.
comments.author: 1400IntruderVS

comments.text:
+1400IntruderVS Nope. Price of the 1961 MOTOR test car (i.e. top spec, 
fastest, best, all the knobs and whistles)... 2k. 2.097 to be precise. 
Apparently.

The US auto industry in the 50s made... what?
60s? Again, little of any value to the industry.
The 70s were a little bit interesting but, err, no. Nothing actually *good*.
Drive a 70s American car today and it's a bit worrying. Drive a Jag from 10 
years previously and it's disks and independent suspension all round with a 
DOHC engine. That sounds... modern. And drives sort of modern too. It'll 
stop, and turn, and go...

When was Jaguar saved by an American company? If you mean Ford, they did 
more damage than good. Poor Jag was left with a shitty reliability record 
thanks to Ford pushing tech out too quick, and a V8 engine that had cost a 
lot, but that Jaguar had never wanted nor needed.

Yes, the jag 12 is quite a time consuming engine... but considering it's 
smoother than 90% of modern engines, I'll forgive it. That a 42 year old 
engine can *still* provide me daily work transport (sometimes up to 
3-400miles in a day) reliably and smoothly... I can't fault it. It's an 
easy engine to work on too, it just takes a while. And have you ever tried 
to swap a cam on a pushrod V8? PAIN IN THE ARSE. With an OHC V12.. piece of 
piss.
Upgrade shmupgrade. If you *need* to upgrade a car, it probably wasn't up 
to scratch in the first place. I upgraded my Jag because it wasn't loud 
enough. Accidentally got a load more power and better economy on the way, 
but the important thing is the noise.
If you want raw simplicity, buy a tractor. If you want a good car... steer 
away from old American stuff. And new American stuff which is still not 
that great but is now also really complex.
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
61 E-type 3.8 265hp @5500 Retailed just over 5500 before tax and tarrif in 
1961.
The US automobile industry was at it's highest during the fifties and into 
the mid seventies so there were no worries then . Partly why build quality 
was simple and poor on most of their products back then. The market focus 
between what Americans expected and what Europeans offered was different 
back then. No need to school me boy I ahve been around long enough and done 
enough hands on research to understand why you do not understand. I have 
worked in shops where we hot roded Porsches and at dealers for all the big 
3 at one time or another. Also a motorcycle geek if it helps but mostly I 
just enjoy the history of things and how we got here.
The here and now where all markets are very competitive because every-ones' 
economy is on the brink of collapse.
Jaguar was once saved by an American company so you should appreciate that 
as well. 
The were cars of great character in the sixties but awful reliability. When 
they worked they were magical but they are not easily serviced and have far 
too many seals that bleed.
I had the pleasure of putting a clutch in an 72 V12 E-type and it was as 
rewarding as it were challenging. I re-sealed the engine whil it was out 
and detailed everything on it's way back together. After such a task it is 
easy to understand why so many people appreciate the raw simplicity of the 
old American cars.
and how easily they can be upgraded as well.
comments.author: 1400IntruderVS

comments.text:
Muscle cars are not sleepers.
I just realized I was wasting time speaking with some of lesser 
comprehension that hasn't been around enough to understand what the 
original point was that I had made. I am a little embarrassed but for whom?
comments.author: 1400IntruderVS

comments.text:
+1400IntruderVS My '61 E type was 2k new. A few hundred was a lot back then.

Thing is... why are muscle cars so celebrated. Drive one, they're 
worryingly crap at stopping, don't steer very well.. They're dangerous. And 
the power isn't really all that much considering a 7.2 litre V8 made as 
much go in a Charger as a 3.8 litre I6 did in my E type, 10 years 
previously. And yes, 4 seater E types existed.

The Beetle was actually a MUCH cheaper, car, the US government just taxes 
the shit out of imports to save its own dying industry. Actually, Ford has 
been almost dying pretty much every decade for the past 5, and GM and 
Chrysler actually did die. If it weren't for that lovely cushy national 
debt...

I wouldn't call any muscle car a sleeper. They're all big, brash, obvious 
and make very loud noises.
An XJ12 on the other hand is quiet, smooth, inconspicuous and could do 
140mph in 1971, which was faster than most of the massive muscle cars, 
incidentally.
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
Simplify every ones understanding of the pricing in sixties wher these cars 
were concerned. The VW Beetle was marketed as a bare bones economy car and 
sold for hundreds more than a well equipped Mustang GT in 1967. the the VW 
was economical to operate it's import status at the time increased its 
retail cost because, well it was more expensive for manufacturers to export 
vehicles back then.
Like wise the domestic luxury market such as Cadillac were priced nearer to 
the 10 mark compared to say a '68 Torino GT around 3700. or 3836 which was 
the sticker of my old car. Which was also close to the sticker of on my 
friends old Beetle 3788 which was more the 3327 for the Mustang I was 
speeking of.
I used to research every car I owned. Like wise many friends (gar guys). 
And I have an assortment of old magazines published of era as well as the 
history from people who were there and nothing indicates the Musclecars 
were anything more the working class guys supercar with exception to a few 
special models such as Boss 302/429 cars. Which were more rare than 
actually expensive in their respected years.
Not trying to argue with any one I am just explaining that as time goes on 
the designation of musclecar has been marketedly mis-represented and 
unfortunately time will distort the meaning as it has most pop-cultural 
history. Like "Sleepers" another word that has lost it's definition to the 
next generation.
comments.author: 1400IntruderVS

comments.text:
They were under the 7k mark which put them less than a 10k corvette and 
more practical. Actually comparably cheaper than today's Mustang or 
Challenger. Whither some exceptions of course. And literally were marketed 
toward middle income average folks and that is just the simple history 
behind it all. No one knew they were to be so celebrated so many years 
later.
comments.author: 1400IntruderVS

comments.text:
+1400IntruderVS A few hundred was a LOT back in the 70s. It was the 
difference between a Rover and a Jaguar, every day, vs luxury.
*OLD* cars are a different matter. I can buy a Rolls Royce today for less 
than the cheapest, shittest new car available. A quarter of what most 
people will spend on an average new car.
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
Most of the big block drag pack optioned cars could be had for a few 
hundred dollars over the base. The did not carry the quarter or third more 
price increase todays  SRT or Shelby variants do. Of course a Shelby was 
always expensive but there were multiple variations on many models that 
offered plenty of oomph for little coin. A tri-power GTO was not going to 
cost ten grand  were as a Ferrari GTO was more than that. 
I come from a working class generation that comes from a working class 
generation before them and not only did my father's brother but many of my 
uncle's and their friends owned such vehicles. Actually in my youth 
(1980s-90s) many of these now ridiculously priced musclecars could still be 
found for a price a High-school kid could afford.
Some of the cars I could have bought for under $1500 in daily driver 
condition when I was kid (some my friends did buy) 69 Mach 1, 70 cyclone GT 
351CJ, 72 440 Challenger, 69 Chevelle 396SS, 68 Torino GT, 73 Mach 1, 72 
Gran Sport Torino, 70 Torino Cobra 429CJ. 66 Chevelle 396 SS.
These cars could be found inexpensive at a time when the Fox platform 
Mustangs were beating on 5.7 Iroc Z28s. 
Prices really didn't boom so high until the second half of the 90s. 
And they went high fast after that.
comments.author: 1400IntruderVS
